16.77.text: It's the fifth time I stand on this shore,

23.80.text: looking out at that distant horizon,

31.89.text: that I'm going to make it all the way

34.45.text:
across that vast,
dangerous wilderness of an ocean.

39.55.text: Not only have I tried four times,

41.30.text:
but the greatest swimmers in the world
have been trying since 1950,

45.85.text: and it's still never been done.

49.38.text: The team is proud of our four attempts.

53.33.text: It's an expedition of some 30 people.

55.88.text: Bonnie is my best friend and head handler,

63.15.text:
that last drop of will within me,
when I think it's gone,

66.93.text: after many, many hours and days out there.

70.53.text:
The shark experts
are the best in the world --

76.69.text:
The box jellyfish, the deadliest venom
in all of the ocean,

83.13.text:
and I have come close to dying from them
on a previous attempt.

90.56.text:
besides the sheer distance
of over 100 miles in the open ocean --

95.85.text:
the currents and whirling eddies
and the Gulf Stream itself,

99.89.text:
the most unpredictable
of all of the planet Earth.

105.64.text: And by the way -- it's amusing to me

109.82.text:
that journalists and people,
before these attempts, often ask me,

114.49.text:
"Well, are you going to go with any boats
or any people or anything?"

119.40.text: And I'm thinking, what are they imagining?

121.56.text:
That I'll just sort of do
some celestial navigation --

125.74.text: And carry a bowie knife in my mouth,

129.27.text:
and I'll hunt fish and skin them
alive and eat them,

132.83.text:
and maybe drag a desalinization plant
behind me for fresh water.

150.61.text:
and brimming with innovation
and scientific discovery,

154.80.text:
as is true of any major
expedition on the planet.

160.04.text: And we've been on a journey.

162.96.text: And the debate has raged, hasn't it,

166.58.text: of isn't it what it's all about?

169.45.text:
Isn't life about the journey,
not really the destination?

174.42.text: And here we've been on this journey,

176.15.text: and the truth is, it's been thrilling.

178.43.text: We haven't reached that other shore,

180.20.text:
and still, our sense
of pride and commitment,

186.11.text:
When I turned 60,
the dream was still alive

190.57.text:
from having tried this in my 20s --
dreamed it and imagined it.

196.30.text:
The most famous body of water
on the Earth today, I imagine,

202.89.text: And it was deep. It was deep in my soul.

209.41.text:
it wasn't so much
about the athletic accomplishment,

212.06.text:
it wasn't the ego
of "I want to be the first."

215.38.text: That's always there and it's undeniable.

219.90.text: It was "how much life is there left?"

221.96.text:
Let's face it -- we're all
on a one-way street, aren't we?

225.22.text: And what are we going to do?

226.79.text:
What are we going to do as we go forward,
to have no regrets looking back?

232.19.text: And all this past year in training,

234.86.text: I had that Teddy Roosevelt quote

237.57.text:
to paraphrase it,
floating around in my brain.

241.68.text:
You go ahead and sit back
in your comfortable chair

244.80.text:
and you be the critic,
you be the observer,

248.78.text:
while the brave one
gets in the ring and engages

252.94.text:
and gets bloody and gets dirty and fails
over and over and over again,

257.42.text:
but yet isn't afraid and isn't timid
and lives life in a bold way."

262.94.text: And so of course I want to make it across.

265.40.text:
It is the goal, and I should
be so shallow to say that this year,

270.67.text:
the destination was even sweeter
than the journey.

279.56.text:
But the journey itself
was worthwhile taking.

282.84.text: And at this point, by this summer,

299.58.text:
It just simply can't be done,
and Bonnie said to me,

302.15.text: "But if you're going to take the journey,

304.16.text:
I'm going to see you
through to the end of it,

312.13.text:
As we're looking out,
kind of a surreal moment

316.36.text: standing on the rocks at Marina Hemingway,

318.88.text: the Cuban flag is flying above,

321.58.text:
all my team is out in their boats,
hands up in the air,

331.02.text: Bonnie and I look at each other and say,

333.13.text:
this year, the mantra is --
and I've been using it in training --

341.87.text:
and you have obstacles
in front of you, as we all do.

344.89.text: None of us ever get through this life

354.38.text: and if you believe and you have faith

357.20.text:
and you can get knocked down
and get back up again

369.12.text:
and she said, "Let's find
our way to Florida."

373.37.text: And we started, and for the next 53 hours,

375.95.text:
it was an intense,
unforgettable life experience.

381.65.text: The highs were high, the awe --

383.89.text:
I'm not a religious person,
but I'll tell you,

386.24.text: to be in the azure blue of the Gulf Stream

391.59.text:
you're looking down miles
and miles and miles,

396.25.text:
to feel the majesty
of this blue planet we live on --

405.06.text: I have a playlist of about 85 songs,

407.56.text:
and especially in the middle
of the night ...

409.69.text:
That night, because we use
no lights -- lights attract jellyfish,

414.05.text:
lights attract baitfish
that attract sharks,

416.44.text: so we go in the pitch black of the night.

418.94.text: You've never seen black this black.

422.27.text: You can't see the front of your hand,

424.36.text:
and the people on the boat,
Bonnie and my team on the boat --

427.37.text: they just hear the slapping of the arms,

429.43.text: and they know where I am,

430.64.text: because there's no visual at all.

432.58.text:
And I'm out there kind of tripping out
on my little playlist.

439.25.text:
I've got tight rubber caps,
I don't hear a thing.

442.32.text:
I've got goggles and I'm turning
my head 50 times a minute,

457.51.text:
And I can sing that song
a thousand times in a row.

462.33.text: Now there's a talent unto itself.

469.41.text: And each time I get done with,

471.81.text:
(Singing) Oh, you may say I'm a dreamer
but I'm not the only one

486.14.text: And when I get through the end

487.68.text: of a thousand of John Lennon's "Imagine,"

489.76.text: I have swum nine hours and 45 minutes ...

496.40.text: And then there are the crises.

500.96.text:
And the vomiting starts,
the seawater -- you're not well.

504.30.text:
You're wearing a jellyfish mask
for the ultimate protection.

509.42.text:
It's causing abrasions
on the inside of the mouth,

512.07.text: but the tentacles can't get you.

517.29.text:
The water's 85 degrees,
and yet you're losing weight

522.04.text:
And as you come over
toward the side of the boat --

524.51.text:
not allowed to touch it,
not allowed to get out,

526.87.text: but Bonnie and her team hand me nutrition

529.02.text: and ask me how I'm doing, am I all right.

532.38.text: I am seeing the Taj Mahal --

537.81.text: I'm in a very different state --

545.78.text:
I never thought I'd be running
into the Taj Mahal out here.

551.45.text:
I mean, how long
did it take them to build that?

562.63.text: We kind of have a cardinal rule

564.52.text:
that I'm never told how far it is,
because we don't know how far it is.

568.01.text:
What's going to happen to you
between this point and that point?

571.21.text:
What's going to happen
to the weather and the currents

575.82.text:
when you don't think you could
be stung in all this armor.

580.39.text:
Bonnie made a decision
coming into that third morning

586.57.text: and I was hanging on by a thread.

591.73.text:
and I came close
to the boat, and she said,

596.24.text: because the day is easier than the night,

598.26.text: and I thought we were coming into day.

600.12.text:
I saw a stream of white light
along the horizon,

603.80.text:
and I said, "It's going
to be morning soon."

606.10.text:
And she said, "No, those
are the lights of Key West."

613.52.text:
which for most swimmers
would be a long time.

622.24.text:
You have no idea how many
15-hour training swims I had done.

626.79.text:
So here we go, and I somehow,
without a decision,

630.63.text: went into no counting of strokes

634.30.text:
and no quoting Stephen Hawking
on the parameters of the universe.

639.52.text:
I just went into thinking
about this dream, and why and how.

646.19.text: As I said, when I turned 60,

648.35.text:
it wasn't about that concrete
"Can you do it?"

655.34.text:
That's the discipline,
and it's the preparation,

658.11.text: and there's a pride in that.

659.84.text: But I decided to think, as I went along,

664.39.text:
about -- you know, the phrase usually is,
"reaching for the stars."

668.28.text:
And in my case,
it's reaching for the horizon.

671.44.text: And when you reach for the horizon,

673.33.text: as I've proven, you may not get there.

676.04.text:
But what a tremendous build
of character and spirit

684.41.text:
what a foundation you lay down
in reaching for those horizons.

689.89.text: And now, the shore is coming.

692.43.text:
And there's just a little part
of me that's sad.

695.58.text: The epic journey is going to be over.

697.82.text: So many people come up to me now and say,

706.92.text: When are you going to do the next one?

708.78.text: We can't wait to follow the next one."

710.64.text: Well, they were just there for 53 hours,

712.84.text: and I was there for years.

715.23.text:
And so there won't be another
epic journey in the ocean.

718.66.text: But the point is, and the point was,

722.23.text: that every day of our lives is epic.

727.42.text:
And I'll tell you,
when I walked up onto that beach,

731.91.text:
I had so many times,
in a very puffed-up ego way,

743.36.text:
When Bonnie thought the back
of my throat was swelling up,

746.33.text:
she brought the medical team
over to our boat

748.52.text:
to say, "She's really beginning
to have trouble breathing;

755.83.text:
the whole thing -- I just thought,
in my hallucinatory moment,

764.87.text:
Bonnie said to the doctor,
"I'm not worried about her not breathing.

768.17.text:
If she can't talk
when she gets to the shore,

770.33.text: she's going to be pissed off."

777.11.text:
But the truth is, all those orations
that I had practiced,

781.04.text:
just to get myself through some
training swims as motivation --

786.43.text: It was a very real moment,

788.91.text: with that crowd, with my team.

791.37.text: We did it. I didn't do it. We did it.

793.88.text:
And we'll never forget it.
It'll always be part of us.

797.18.text:
The three things I did sort of blurt out
when we got there, was first:

805.98.text:
What's the phrase
from today from Socrates?

808.87.text: Audience: To be is to do.

810.09.text: Diana Nyad: To be is to do.

811.42.text:
So I don't stand up and say,
"Don't ever give up."

816.34.text: There was action behind these words.

820.01.text:
You can chase your dreams
at any age; you're never too old.

823.31.text:
Sixty-four; a thing no one,
at any age, any gender, could ever do

829.59.text: And there's no doubt in my mind

831.16.text: that I am at the prime of my life today.

844.08.text:
And the third thing
I said on that beach was,

846.25.text:
it looks like the most solitary
endeavor in the world,

848.92.text: and in many ways, of course, it is.

851.05.text:
And in other ways,
and the most important ways,

855.94.text:
And if you think I'm a badass,
you want to meet Bonnie.

873.40.text: The Henry David Thoreau quote goes,

875.74.text:
"When you achieve your dreams,
it's not so much what you get

879.04.text: as who you have become in achieving them."

881.90.text: And yeah, I stand before you now.

883.84.text: In the three months since that swim ended,

887.69.text:
and I've been in
President Obama's Oval Office;

891.47.text:
I've been invited to speak
in front of esteemed groups

895.22.text:
I've signed a wonderful
major book contract.

897.50.text:
All of that's great,
and I don't denigrate it.

900.23.text: I'm proud of it all, but the truth is,

903.47.text:
because I am that bold, fearless person,
and I will be, every day,

909.43.text: until it's time for these days to be done.

913.61.text:
Thank you very much
and enjoy the conference.

920.68.text:
Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.
Thank you! Thank you.
